Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: The use of logging and surface NMR measurements to estimate hydraulic conductivity in unconsolidated aquifers
Award.AbstractNarration:
THE USE OF LOGGING AND SURFACE NMR MEASUREMENTS
TO ESTIMATE HYDRAULIC CONDUCTIVITY IN UNCONSOLIDATED AQUIFERS
Rosemary Knight (PI), Stanford University
Yi-Qiao Song (Co-PI), Schlumberger-Doll Research

There are growing concerns, worldwide, about the sustainability of our groundwater resources. The critical decisions that must be made, in order to manage and protect our water resources, require accurate characterization of the properties of groundwater aquifers that govern both the storage and movement of water. The focus of this research project is the use of NMR (nuclear magnetic resonance) logging and surface-based NMR as a means of determining hydraulic conductivity (K) in the saturated zone of an unconsolidated aquifer from measurement of NMR relaxation times.
NMR logging involves lowering an instrument into a borehole to measure the NMR relaxation times of hydrogen protons in the pore water of the surrounding geological material. NMR logging has been used for many years for petroleum applications to estimate the properties of petroleum reservoirs such as water-filled porosity, pore-size distribution, and permeability. There is now a growing interest in the use of NMR logging for groundwater applications to obtain estimates of K in unconsolidated or weakly consolidated aquifer materials. A key question to be addressed in our research: How can we obtain reliable estimates of K from NMR logging measurements in unconsolidated aquifers?
Over the past decade, there has been great interest in a new, and very different way of making NMR measurements using Earth?s magnetic field and a system located at the surface. A non-invasive, surface-based NMR method, referred to as magnetic resonance sounding (MRS), has been developed and used to measure the NMR response of groundwater aquifers and obtain estimates of K. There are two outstanding questions related to this technology that will be addressed in this research: What is actually measured as the parameter currently taken to represent the NMR relaxation time in the MRS measurement? How can we obtain reliable estimates of K from MRS measurements in unconsolidated materials?
Our vision, and the motivation for the research, is the development of a new approach to NMR-based aquifer characterization that 1) is grounded in an improved understanding of the relationship between the NMR response and K of unconsolidated materials and 2) builds on the best of both technologies in an integrated way. Our approach will allow us to explore new ways of integrating the two forms of NMR measurement to obtain improved subsurface models of NMR properties, and of K. Our proposed research includes laboratory experiments and numerical modeling. In addition, we will conduct a field experiment near Lexington, Nebraska where both logging and surface-based NMR measurements will be made over the 90 to 120 m thick Ogallala aquifer. This proposal represents a unique opportunity for collaboration by bringing together a research group at Stanford, with expertise in NMR laboratory measurements, theory and modeling; a research group at the U.S. Geological Survey with an ongoing project to study MRS; and key industrial partners, Schlumberger-Doll Research (SDR) and Schlumberger Water Services (SWS), with expertise in the acquisition and interpretation of NMR logging, and Vista Clara, Inc., with expertise in the acquisition and interpretation of MRS data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Throughout the world, there is increasing use of groundwater as a source of freshwater. An essential component in the evaluation and management of groundwater resources is determining the amount of producible water held in groundwater aquifers. This involves estimating the amount of water present and the hydraulic conductivity, the ease with which the water can flow through the geological material. There is a form of geophysical measurement, nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), which can potentially provide this information. These NMR measurements can be made by lowering instruments in wells, referred to as NMR logging, and from the surface using a wire loop, referred to as surface NMR.

NMR logging is a well-established method in petroleum applications. This project was the first detailed study of the use of NMR logging for groundwater applications to obtain estimates of hydraulic conductivity in groundwater aquifers. Petroleum applications typically involve NMR measurements on consolidated rocks, while groundwater aquifers can be composed of unconsolidated sediments. We suspected that this difference in the type of geological material would require a new approach to interpreting the NMR data. We acquired NMR logging data in a well at a field site in Nebraska, along with direct measurements of hydraulic conductivity. We explored, with this field data set and with laboratory and numerical studies, the way in which the standard approach to interpreting NMR data, used in petroleum applications, needed to be modified for groundwater applications. We concluded from our work that NMR logging could provide accurate estimates of hydraulic conductivity in groundwater aquifers. Over the past three years, a small company has developed a new NMR logging tool, designed specifically for use in groundwater wells. It is very likely that NMR logging will become an established method for characterizing groundwater aquifers.

Surface NMR is a relatively new technology that can non-invasively (no well required) measure the NMR response to a depth of 100 m. If we could obtain estimates of hydraulic conductivity in groundwater aquifers using this method, it would be extremely useful in the evaluation and management of our groundwater resources. While the physics of the surface NMR measurement is very similar to the NMR logging measurement, there were numerous outstanding questions at the start of our project about the surface NMR method. Both NMR logging and surface NMR provide a measurement of an NMR parameter that can be related to hydraulic conductivity, but the surface NMR measurement is very sensitive to variations in the background magnetic field, i.e. the environment in which the measurement is made. This can result in inaccurate estimates of hydraulic conductivity. The laboratory and theoretical studies that we conducted revealed the importance of accounting for this field variation, and provided insights into the type of variation likely to be present in geological materials. Through laboratory and field experiments, we investigated alternate ways to acquire surface NMR data that could minimize or correct for the impact of this effect on the surface NMR data. Ongoing research is now focused on this issue.

We found that the best way to improve our understanding of the surface NMR measurement was to compare it to the NMR logging measurement. During this project we acquired both logging and surface NMR data at the field site in Nebraska allowing, for the first time, a direct comparison of these two methods at the same location. Our laboratory and theoretical studies complemented these field results and provided clear evidence of the factors that control the way in which each form of NMR measurement is related to hydraulic conductivity.
